tutorial.select-label-type-1: In this Street View image, we have drawn an arrow to a drop kerb. Let’s label it. Click the flashing "Drop Kerb" button above.
tutorial.label-attribute-1: Good! Now click the drop kerb beneath the flashing yellow arrow to label it.
tutorial.rate-severity-1: Now you can rate the quality of the drop kerb where 1 is passable and 5 is not passable for a wheelchair user. Because it is wide enough and has a tactile warning, let’s rate it as 1, passable.
tutorial.redo-rate-attribute-1: Uh-oh, you should rate this drop kerb as 1, passable. It is a high quality drop kerb that is wide enough and has a tactile warning. Let’s click "1" to set its quality.
tutorial.select-label-type-3: Great! Now you’ve found another drop kerb. Let’s label it! Click the “Drop Kerb” button like before.
tutorial.label-attribute-3: Now click the drop kerb beneath the flashing yellow arrow to label it.
tutorial.rate-severity-3: Good, now rate the quality of the drop kerb.
tutorial.redo-rate-attribute-3: Uh-oh, you should rate this drop kerb as 2, somewhat passable. It is a high quality drop kerb but it has no landing space at the top of the drop kerb for making turns. Let’s click "2" to set its quality.
tutorial.tag-attribute-3: Every label includes optional tags that add descriptive information. Choose appropriate tags for every label you place! Let's add the “not enough landing space” tag because there is not enough space for a wheelchair user to turn when they get to the top of the drop kerb.
tutorial.redo-tag-attribute-3: Only the "not enough landing space" tag applies here, since the drop kerb has a tactile warning, is not too narrow nor steep, and does not point into traffic. So add only the "not enough landing space" tag.
tutorial.select-label-type-4: Notice that there is no drop kerb at the end of this pedestrian crossing. Click the "Missing Drop Kerb" button to label it.
tutorial.label-attribute-4: Now click beneath the flashing yellow arrow to label the missing drop kerb.
tutorial.rate-severity-4: Since this missing drop kerb is next to an existing drop kerb, this accessibility problem is less severe. So let’s rate it as a 3. When you rate accessibility, we just ask that you use your best judgment!
tutorial.redo-rate-attribute-4: Hmm, since this missing drop kerb is next to an existing drop kerb, this accessibility problem is less severe. Let’s click "3" to change the severity of the missing drop kerb.
tutorial.tag-attribute-4: Let's add the "alternate route present" tag because there is a nearby drop kerb that could be used.
tutorial.redo-tag-attribute-4: The "alternate route present" tag is the only tag that applies here because there is a nearby drop kerb that could be used. So add only the "alternate route present" tag.
tutorial.select-label-type-7: Notice that the footpath suddenly ends here. Let’s label this. Click the "No Footpath" button to label it.
tutorial.label-attribute-7: Click on the ground where the footpath is missing.
tutorial.rate-severity-7: Since there is a footpath on the other side of the street, this accessibility problem is less severe. So let’s rate it as a 3.
tutorial.redo-rate-attribute-7: Hmm, since there is a footpath on the other side of the street, this accessibility problem is less severe. Let’s click "3" to change the severity of the no footpath label.
tutorial.tag-attribute-7: Let's add the "ends abruptly" and "street has a footpath" tags because there is a footpath on the other side of the street.
tutorial.redo-tag-attribute-7: The "ends abruptly" and "street has a footpath" tags are the only tags that apply here. So make sure to add only those two tags.
tutorial.adjust-heading-angle-4: Awesome! Let’s finish labeling the last drop kerb in the intersection. First, grab and drag the Street View image.
tutorial.select-label-type-8: Good! Now click the "Drop Kerb" button on the menu to label it.
tutorial.label-attribute-8: Click the drop kerb beneath the flashing yellow arrow to label it.
tutorial.rate-severity-8: Now rate the drop kerb’s quality. Use your best judgment. You can also write notes in the Description Box.
tutorial.redo-rate-attribute-8: Hmm, you should rate this drop kerb as 1, passable. This drop kerb is wide enough, has a tactile warning, and doesn't point into traffic. Let’s click "1" to change its rating.
tutorial.walk-5-1: Now you can look for more issues at this location. In this case, notice how there is a pedestrian crossing with pedestrian signals but no drop kerbs at either end.
tutorial.walk-5-2: Yes! I see the missing drop kerbs.

current-mission.message-first-mission: Explore for __PLACEHOLDER__ and find all the footpath accessibility attributes

compass.end-neighborhood:
You've explored this entire neighbourhood! Finish labeling this intersection, then
click here to complete the neighbourhood.

popup.start-body: We have moved you to a street in {{neighborhood}}, {{city}}! You are currently standing at the intersection. Please find and label all the drop kerbs and accessibility problems at this intersection.
popup.label-shortcuts-curb-ramp: You can also press the <kbd>{{key}}</kbd> key for selecting the Drop Kerb label.
popup.label-shortcuts-no-curb-ramp: You can also press the <kbd>{{key}}</kbd> key for selecting the Missing Drop Kerb label.
popup.label-shortcuts-no-sidewalk: You can also press the <kbd>{{key}}</kbd> key for selecting the No Footpath label.
popup.label-shortcuts-crosswalk: You can also press the <kbd>{{key}}</kbd> key for selecting the Pedestrian Crossing label.
popup.label-shortcuts-occlusion: You can also press the <kbd>{{key}}</kbd> key for selecting the Can't See the Footpath label.
